docs.snippet: At the height of the protests early Sunday evening, about 200 demonstrators marched in the heart of downtown, stopping traffic and shouting, “No justice, no peace, no racist police!”...
docs.lead_paragraph: At the height of the protests early Sunday evening, about 200 demonstrators marched in the heart of downtown, stopping traffic and shouting, “No justice, no peace, no racist police!”
docs.abstract: Cleveland police expect protests to escalate during Republican National Convention; 2,500 law enforcement officers from across nation are assisting in policing event.

headline.main: A Civil Start to Protests, but Cleveland Is Bracing for Worse
headline.print_headline: Civil so Far, Cleveland Is Bracing for Worse

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Nick Corasaniti and Colin Moynihan in Cleveland.
byline.original: By YAMICHE ALCINDOR and ALAN RAPPEPORT

docs.snippet: Cleveland and Philadelphia, with areas of gleaming renewal and others of crushing poverty, illustrate the plight of America’s cities, little discussed in the campaign....
docs.lead_paragraph: Cleveland and Philadelphia, with areas of gleaming renewal and others of crushing poverty, illustrate the plight of America’s cities, little discussed in the campaign.
docs.abstract: Cleveland and Philadelphia, hosts to Republican and Democratic National Conventions, contain both neighborhoods undergoing gentrification and renewal and areas of grievous poverty; cities' poverty rates, respectively, are 39.2 percent and 26 percent; both cities have very segregated black populations.

headline.main: Sparkling and Blighted, Convention Cities Spotlight Ignored Urban Issues
headline.print_headline: Cities as Political Stage, but Not Campaign Topic

docs.snippet: American political conventions once had real drama as parties held rounds and rounds of voting before settling on a presidential nominee.  Now, they are highly staged television pep rallies as party loyalists anoint a nominee determined in state p...
docs.lead_paragraph: American political conventions once had real drama as parties held rounds and rounds of voting before settling on a presidential nominee.  Now, they are highly staged television pep rallies as party loyalists anoint a nominee determined in state primaries and caucuses.

headline.main: AP EXPLAINS: Do US Political Conventions Still Matter?
